title: samantha csik
text:
education
MS in Ecology, Evolution & Marine Biology, 2020 – University of California, Santa Barbara, Santa Barbara, CA
BS in Marine Biology, 2016 – Northeastern University, Boston, MA



experience
Data Training Coordinator (2021-present) - National Center for Ecological Analysis & Synthesis, University of California, Santa Barbara, CA
Data Science Fellow (2020-2021) - National Center for Ecological Analysis & Synthesis, University of California, Santa Barbara, CA

title: about
text:
Map last updated: August 3, 2022


I feel very fortunate to be doing so many of things that I love a lot right now. That includes my job, but also spending lots of time outdoors. Living in Santa Barbara is a massive privilege and being here means that we have access to both the mountains and the sea, each a few minutes in either direction. It was the ocean that brought me here originally, but most of my free time is now spent on the trails.
I started recording my hikes (and eventually some other activitiess) on Strava in late 2020 and finally got around to scraping my activity data using the rStrava package. Above is a heatmap of all my recorded activities made using leaflet. I’m still mulling over a better way to display markers and popup information, as the markers overlap a lot at my most frequented trailheads. Huge shout out to Daniel Cullen (who also happens to be a Santa Barbara resident!) for his awesome blogpost that got me started with my own map.
You can check out the source code on GitHub.

title: resources
text: It’s finally time for an upgraded notebook! I’ve been Slacking myself (and subsequently burying) links to resources for far too long, so my favorites will now live here.

title: resources
text:
r tools

free icons from fontawesome + the {fontawesome} R package for infusing your {xaringan} slides, website, RMarkdowns, and more with an extra splash of fun

title: resources
text:
data viz

from Data to Viz, a choose-your-adventure-type experience for creating your best data visualizations
The Sessions College Color Calculator, for creating color palettes

title: resources
text:
reporting & presentations

Quarto is all the rage these days (and by these days, I mean post-March 2022). Download and find some great tutorials here to get started
Meet xaringan: Making slides in R Markdown, by Allison Hill
Sharing Your xaringan Slides, by Garrick Aden-Buie

title: resources
text:
learning materials

Ever feel like you need a pick-me-up while learning stats or a new R tool? Look no further than Allison Horst’s R & stats illustrations, featuring the cutest and most educational fuzzy monsters you’ll ever see!
Mastering Shiny, by Hadley Wickham
Happy Git and GitHub for the useR, by Jenny Bryan
R for Data Science, by Hadley Wickham

title: resources
text:
data science communities
While these groups are primarily based in SoCal/Santa Barbara, there are tons of awesome groups like these all over the world. Google around to see what’s near you!

R-Ladies Santa Barbara and R-Ladies Global, which work to promote gender diversity in the R community
EcoDataScience, an environmental data science study group at UCSB
Southern California R Users, an alliance of R user groups in Southern California
Santa Barbara Women in STEM, while not specifically data science-focused, this group holds some really great career and networking events, panels, flash talks, and more

title: resources
text:
web accessibility

The A11Y Project is a community-driven effort to make digital content more accessible. I still have a long way to go in making my own website WCAG compliant – the A11Y Project not only has a ton of great blog posts, but also WCAG compliance checklist that I will definitely be returning to over and over again.
Coblis, a color blindness simulator – just upload a file and view your color palettes as they would appear under different types of color deficiencies

text:
